snippet: The recession and anemic recovery are behind most of a surprising trend that could help close the federal deficit, new studies show, but higher co-payments have also played a part.
abstract: Studies by researchers at Harvard University and Henry J Kaiser Family Foundation concur that at least some of bigger-than-expected slowdown in health spending over last few years is unrelated to recession, and might persist as economy recovers; find that rising out-of-pocket costs have played major role decline.
lead_paragraph: The recession and anemic recovery are behind most of a surprising trend that could help close the federal deficit, new studies show, but higher co-payments have also played a part.
